statement:
The alternating group $A_{n}$ is a normal subgroup of the symmetric
group $S_{n}$

Define the epimorphism $f:S_{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{Z}_2$ by
$:\sigma\mapsto 0$ if $\sigma$ is an even permutation and
$:\sigma\mapsto 1$ if $\sigma$ is an odd permutation. Hence, $A_{n}$ is
the kernel of $f$ and so it is a normal subgroup of the domain $S_{n}$.
Furthermore $S_{n}/A_{n}\cong\mathbb{Z}_2$ by the first isomorphism
theorem. So by Lagrange’s theorem
$$\vert S_{n} \vert=\vert A_{n} \vert\vert S_{n}/A_{n}\vert.$$
Therefore, $\vert A_{n}\vert=n!/2$. That is, there are $n!/2$ many
elements in $A_{n}$

**Remark**. What we have shown in the theorem is that, in fact, $A_n$
has index $2$ in $S_n$. In general, if a subgroup $H$ of $G$ has index
$2$, then $H$ is normal in $G$. (Since $[G:H]=2$, there is an element
$g\in G-H$, so that $gH\cap H=\varnothing$ and thus $gH=Hg$).
names: alternating group is a normal subgroup of the symmetric group
